1.val: If all the world should twist and twine, Still be thou straight as plummet line.

2.val: Never look for a knot in a bulrush.

3.val: Don’t look for difficulties where there are none.

4.val: Never look for a ram with five feet.

5.val: Expect not the abnormal, the monstrous, the singular. Leave “the Derby ram” to those who are in love with penny shows.

6.val: Never look for pippins on a crab-tree.

7.val: Everything yields according to its nature. Sour yields sour, and it would be folly to look for sweet from it.

9.val: It will come soon enough, and then you will meet it where God meant you should meet it, and where he will help you to bear it.

10.val: Never mind who was your grandfather: what are you?

11.val: The man who has nothing to boast of but his good ancestors, is like a potato: all that is good of him is under ground. So said an author long since under ground himself.

13.val: It is a sort of treachery to do so: like Absalom inviting Amnon to a feast to kill him.

14.val: Never offer to teach fish to swim.

15.val: They know better than you do. It is absurd for young green-horns to set up to instruct experienced persons.

16.val: Never overdrive The best horse alive.

17.val: He is just the horse you ought to take care of. If he be a weak horse it is cruel to overdrive him, and if he is a willing horse it is unfair to take advantage of him.

18.val: Never play with a mad dog.

19.val: Or you will soon have cause to repent of your play. Do not sport with sin, or speculate in false doctrine. Keep out of the way when a man is in a savage temper.

21.val: And then it is too late to foretell. We had better not so despise prophesyings as to think ourselves capable of manufacturing them.

22.val: Never put your finger between the anvil and the hammer.

23.val: Keep clear of violent opponents when they are in full action, or you may receive upon yourself the force of their blows.

24.val: Who interferes gets double blow: It’s not my business, off I go.

25.val: Never put your hand into a wasp’s nest.

26.val: It will be prudent to respect the quiet of that domestic circle. Even if a man does not regard the rights of others, it may often be wise for him to consider his own peace before he commences to meddle.

28.val: “Let another man praise thee, and not thine own mouth.” — - Proverbs 27:2.

30.val: Trust not the man who has failed you. Moreover, he who has been a bankrupt once is very apt to fail a second time: be cautious.

31.val: Thou didst deceive: the fault was thine. A second time it will be mine.

32.val: Never roast so as to burn, nor sport so as to sin.

33.val: Observe the bounds of righteousness, kindness, and truth.

34.val: Never say die! Up, man, and try!

35.val: Despondency does nothing; perseverance works wonders.

36.val: Never say die till you’re dead, and then it’s no use.

37.val: Bravely hold on, and do not give way to despondency under any circumstances whatever. (Easier said than done.)

38.val: Never say of another what you would not have him hear.

39.val: This precept would put the extinguisher on many a tattler.

40.val: Never sell your customers by selling bad goods.

41.val: It will be a rogue’s action, and in the long run you will sell yourself, and be obliged to shut up shop.

43.val: Some do so habitually. If they can live on others they will not do a hand’s turn. The age of chivalry is over, but the age of loafers lasts for ever. Let us be of another clan.

45.val: Do not long for a thing despondingly, but do your best to get it, if it is to be had, and is really desirable.

46.val: Never speak ill of those whose bread you eat.

47.val: Even a dog knows who feeds him. If he bites his keeper, he is likely to be hanged, and nobody will pity him.

48.val: A wise head makes a still tongue.

49.val: A wise man knows his own want of wisdom. This is a sure token of his wisdom.
